page.title: 04FARMING Local changes (1)
page.content: From the time of the Domesday Book to about 150 years ago, little had changed.At the time of the Industrial Revolution,many left the country and moved into the towns.The rich people set up large estates,like Possingworth Manor, which gave work to many people. People lived and worked around the village.Sometimes people had to walk 7 or 8 miles to work.They took the shortest routes and made some of the footpaths we have today. Few places had electricity,water was pumped from wells,butter was churned and crops were cut and chopped by hand. Due to problems,estates began to break up and workers rented land for their own use. After the First World War,factories made more machines and farmers only needed a few workers.Food came in from abroad and farms became derelict. (Lisa Gausden,Sophie Roy,Keith Hunt.)
